Course Description: Field programmable gate arrays (FPGAs) are the first choice for implementation of digital systems due to their distributed and parallel architecture. FPGAs also allows complete control over arithmetic.

Course Outcomes.CO1: Students are able to design and implement sequential and combinational logic design on FPGA
Course Outcomes.CO2: Students are able to write Verilog code to integrate on-board FPGA switches, VGA interface, memory, embedded hardware units etc.
Course Outcomes.CO3: Students are able to implement the algorithms using HLS.
Course Outcomes.CO4: Students are able to design new IP with appropriate AXI interface

Weekly Lecture Plan.Lecture Topic: Theory: FPGA Architecture (CLB, BRAM, DSP48) Lab: Combinational logic design, Synchronous and asynchronous logic design and arithmetic circuits
Weekly Lecture Plan.Assignments: Lab + Homework: Verilog code, simulation and implementation: Comparators, Decoders/Encoders, code converters, ALU, counters, pulse-width modulation, Fibonacci

Weekly Lecture Plan.Lecture Topic: Theory: FPGA Architecture (Clock) Lab: IP, Finite state machines
Weekly Lecture Plan.Assignments: Lab + Homework: Door lock code, traffic lights, sequence detectors etc.

Weekly Lecture Plan.Lecture Topic: Theory: AXI protocol Lab: VGA based game design
Weekly Lecture Plan.Assignments: Lab + Homework: VGA stripes, screen saver, Video game

Weekly Lecture Plan.Lecture Topic: Theory: HLS Design flow Lab: Algorithms to Architecture
Theory: Ultrascale Architecture Lab: HLS Design Flow

Textbook: D. Harris and S. Harris, “Digital Design and Computer Architecture”, Morgan Kauffmann, 2012.
R. Haskell and D. Hanna, “Learning by example using Verilog advanced digital design”, LBE Books, 2014
